item.title: How Bulgaria Is Closing In on Joining the Euro Area
item.description: Bulgaria has gotten the all-clear from two key European Union institutions to adopt the euro in January 2026. The bloc’s executive arm, the European Commission, and the European Central Bank said in separate reports that all the requirements on issues including inflation and public debt have been fulfilled.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Bulgarian central bank in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Bulgaria is poised to hold a seventh general election in less than four years as a final attempt to form a government failed after the Black Sea nation went to the polls in June. Photographer: Michaela Vatcheva/Bloomberg

item.title: US Is Reworking Subsidy Awards to Chipmakers, Lutnick Says
item.description: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the Trump administration has been reworking agreements forged with semiconductor makers under the 2022 Chips Act to secure what he called better terms aimed at generating additional domestic investment.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: A bare wafer stacker sorts silicon wafers in Building 51 at Micron Technology Inc. headquarters in Boise, Idaho, US, on Monday, June 10, 2024. The US announced in April its plans to award Micron Technology Inc. $6.1 billion in grants and as much as $7.5 billion in loans to help the memory-chip maker build new American factories, rounding out a slew of major federal awards for advanced semiconductor manufacturing. Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg

item.title: Netherlands May Hold Elections as Early as Oct. 29
item.description: The Netherlands may hold a general election as early as Oct. 29, after far-right leader Geert Wilders pulled his Freedom Party out of the Dutch government when his coalition partners rejected his latest proposals to curb immigration.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

item.title: EU, US See Progress in Talks Despite Trump Steel Tariff Hike
item.description: The European Union and the US are headed in the “right direction” in trade talks, though new American levies on steel and aluminum imports aren’t helpful if both sides want to maintain momentum, Maros Sefcovic said after meeting with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Maros Sefcovic, vice president of the European Commission, delivers a keynote speech on Brexit at Bloomberg LP's headquarters in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 29, 2022. The UK's plan to override the part of the Brexit deal governing trade in Northern Ireland won't work, Sefcovic said, stressing that the bloc wants an “enduring” partnership with Britain, and won’t contemplate establishing a hard border on the island of Ireland. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
